item.title: Briefing 1 on the EU Referendum: Will the UK have influence over the EU's future as a member?
item.description:
The potential risks associated with remaining in the EU due to its future trajectory have been a subject of debate during the Brexit referendum. Some argue that the UK might be forced into accepting an EU army, further integration of the single currency, or other undesirable developments. However, the crucial point is whether the UK possesses the power to govern such advancements, either through veto or opting out. This analysis will address the key concerns related to continued EU membership, demonstrating how the UK maintains control through opt-outs or veto power in each scenario...

item.title: Is the agreement between the EU and Turkey on refugees and migration considered a treaty?
item.description:

Concerns arose because the agreement bypassed the standard EU treaty procedure outlined in Article 218 TFEU. The Parliament seeks clarification on whether the Council views this statement as a binding treaty and, if not, whether Turkey is aware of its non-binding status...

item.description:

Additionally, the 2014 Dogan judgment addressed the standstill clause in the EU-Turkey Association Agreement concerning family reunification for self-employed Turkish nationals...

item.title: Assessing the Legal Implications of the EU/Turkey Refugee Deal
item.description:
Steve Peers analyzes the legal and political implications of the recent EU-Turkey agreement on refugees. The agreement, while legally controversial, aims to address the refugee crisis and restore order. A key point of contention is the return of migrants arriving in Greece to Turkey. While the agreement states this will be done in accordance with international law, returning all migrants without considering individual circumstances raises concerns about collective expulsion, a violation of EU and international law...

item.title: Evaluating the new proposal on "Safe countries of origin
item.description:
Steve Peers The EU Commission recently introduced several new immigration and asylum initiatives. Three proposals, in particular, suggest binding measures: a temporary relocation measure for asylum-seekers, a permanent relocation system for asylum-seekers, and a regulation establishing a common list of “safe countries of origin.” This list would include Western Balkan countries and Turkey. This article will focus on the “safe country of origin” rules. It’s important to note that the UK, Ireland, and Denmark are not subject to these measures...
